Hugh Wade,
Have you ever had a seat at a table where contract negotiations are going on ?
Back in the early 1970's to 1980, I sat on the union side of the table negotiating, three, three year labor contracts.
Twice we had a special negotiator from the International Union offices to help us because the employer group hired a professional negotiator. 
Twice we ended up having the NLRB come in to mediate when our talks hit a wall and strike votes taken.
Each side came to the table like poker players at a high stake game. We used whatever position of power we had plus we "exaggerated" or bluffed to some extent what we prepared to do if our terms were not met. They did the same.
 Fire and brimstone is putting it mildly. Demeaning language by the employers several times to describe female employees (our team was all female too).  One employer in particular referred to women as c--ts. They said we used our "breasts" (t--s) to think with. Dirty tricks and illegal labor practices were used too.

I feel many coaches make the game too hard. I realize the size and speed of defenses really affect the offensive game plan. Coaches and players spend hours watching film and looking for cracks where 1/10th of a second makes the difference. Ever since I was a little kid the game always comes down to who blocks and tackles the best. Who can cause turnovers. Who can keep away from stupid penalties and mistakes. It's really pretty basic. Only the strong survive, not only physically but mentally.  I think coaches need to back off and let the players play. Let the QB call the majority of plays. Let the defensive linebackers call the formations. Let the coaches run players in and out keeping them fresh. Once you can establish field position, then open things up and strike when odds are in your favor. Teams need more discipline including the coaches. That's why the Patriots are favored.Denver can beat these guys if they play together and keep focus. This team isn't used to having butts kicked.

I agree with you on several of your points. Yes whenever possible tame cats in colonies are put up for adoption so they can have a loving home. Feral kittens 8 was and under are tamed, fixed and adopted. Many times even 3-4 month feral cats can be tamed, fixed and adopted, this can often be more time intensive however. Even some feral adult cats will become friendly, however that can take much longer and time can be spent making sure more feral and pet cats are fixed to be effective in reducing the number of unwanted cats. In my experience, the real problem is people who don’t fix their pet cats, they sell or give away unfixed kittens to people who are going to continue that cycle. We need more super affordable, convenient spay neuter clinics for sure to prevent future unwanted cats. Outdoor enclosures (catios) are great, cat advocates are big supporters of them. Most people who help feral and cats in various ways, doing TNR, fostering, donating do adopt as many cats as possible.

There used to be a Greater Anchorage Area Borough and a City of Anchorage (the Borough was the equivalent of a county).  In 1975 the city of Anchorage and the GAAB merged to form the Municipality of Anchorage.  After the merger, some services were available Municipality wide, while others (such as police, fire and road maintenance services) were put is special tax districts, so if you live in an area that pays the tax assessment, you get the service, and if you don't live in an area that pays, you don't get the service.  The property tax rates in places without services (such as police) have a lower mill rate than places with the services, which pay a higher rate.

We are born racist. To think otherwise is a guilt-defensive tactic, a delusional salve.
Due to our ancestral brain we can only easily process up to 150 people in social cognition and communication. The brain always strives for the familiar and is wary of unfamiliar strangers.
For millenia, humans have extended social cognition to family, extended family, tribe and village. If a stranger has features that do not match the familiar (skin colour, body structure, facial structure, language, accent within the same language, gestures, habits, clothing, etc), the brain treats them as "other","outsider", "potential foe". This triggers both the "friend or foe" and the "fight or flight" imperatives. Neither imperative leads to progress in race relations. We must consciously learn to bypass these ancestral brain imperatives.
For each and every generation, we are born ignorant and egocentric and must be taught how to learn and how to share. We are born racist and must be taught how to accept.

Usually, if you're in a special situation (with infants, or with large luggage or a large instrument), you cannot use the automated check-in machines. I have had this issue flying with a Cello (that I bought a seat for) and with someone that required accommodations (pre booked). Also worth noting, you cannot pre-book seats selection if a leg of your flight is booked through another star alliance member, no matter how much you want to pay. The only way to *try* to get around this is by buying business class tickets and getting the airline to try to accommodate you with phone tag (i do not recommend) because they're just more helpful with business class. This is a pain in the ass with international flights because even though you may book a flight through Air Canada, or Lufthansa, the flight may be actually run by Swiss or any other Star Alliance member. And no, it makes no sense to book each leg with a different airline, you'll end up pay 5-10k for a flight.

The book is The Second Church by Ramsay MacMullin and is of interest because it points out just how people on their own, apart from clerical directions, understood and practiced faith. It has a discussion of the archeology of the first known house church, in Dura, present-day Iraq. And a fascinating description of a cathedral built right over the cemetery places where people feasted together with their dead--pouring a bit in wine through an opening in the grave. We (perhaps just I) usually think of house churches as early, but this Second Church, right after the religion became official, offers a glimpse into a quite different landscape of practice. It also makes it easier to understand how people could have listened to Chrysostom's sermons about sex: they didn't, because the only people in his cathedral were upper class, and the elite men had complete license to do what they m might. The bulk of the people just were not there at all. We are all congregational in our beginnings.

A law to "make it clear that an unconscious person cannot consent to sexual activity" is utterly redundant; no court or sane lawyer has ever questioned that. Obviously, by definition of unconsciousness, an unconscious person is incapable of giving or refusing consent.

There is a related and more difficult question. Can a person, while conscious, give advance consent to sexual activity while unconscious? The Supreme Court of Canada has answered that question in the negative, and by doing so has potentially opened a serious can of worms. Many people in established relationships enjoy being awakened by their partner's intimate touch; however, as it stands any such touch constitutes an assault. You may have been married and sleeping together for years while enjoying an active and varied sex life, but if you touch your sleeping bed partner for a sexual purpose you are committing sexual assault. I think that law needs to be changed to make it clear that advance consent is good consent.

I retired from teaching in 2014 and there was a marked change in kids' fixation on computer games during my final 5 - 10 years. At recess and lunch-hour, a dominant topic among the kids was their games: Minecraft, Grand Theft Auto, various motorcycle-riding simulators, etc.
As students headed for the bus at the end of the day they would discuss what level they were at, what level they hoped to achieve that evening, who they'd be playing with, etc.

Others were into rap videos, even whispers of porn sites, perhaps even worse.

Parents complained that they couldn't get their kid in bed... they'd catch him playing at midnight, then he'd refuse to get up & go to school. 

Students who misbehaved openly said, "Good... send me home. I'd much rather play ___ than be in school."

I think the ballooning obesity rate is due more to screen time than it is to diet. Some kids would rather play than eat...much less socialize in the real world.

Most work study jobs are students working as tutors or in college department offices.  Work study is awarded two ways need based and merit based.  Need based is because yours and your family income is below a certain level. Merit based because the job you have is helping you with your future career goals. Work study is helpful because many campus employers want to hire students with work study because the work study award pays part of the student's pay check - thus not out of the department's budget. We have students who work for us who do not want work study because it means they have less available they can borrow on student loans (poor decision in my opinion). It is still possible to get jobs without work study.  How many students work their way through school working at department stores, restaurants, convenience stores, or other on campus non-work study jobs?  Quite a few and they can still do so.

Tides are extremely important when considering a bar crossing, walk on the beach etc.  Tides always make   a difference of when you can SAFELY cross the bar.    Sometimes we have to wait until midnight, 2am. to  safely cross,   all based on how deep the water is at the bar.  Low depth at bar usually means you will have to wait a hour or two before you cross.  Other factors, swell direction, wind direction, time between swells, it all enters into when you can go.  Talk about tides.  Here in Oregon our CHANGEOVER,( the difference measured in feet between high and low tide),  is anywhere from a minus 2 feet to 9-10 feet.     On average its usually somewhere between 5-7 feet.  NOW,  up in Cook Inlet Alaska,  @ NINILCHIK,  the CHANGEOVER can be anywhere  from minus 2 feet to 40 feet.    This month of January there is around a 20 foot changeover.    HUGE, MONSTROUS, tide changeovers.  You do not see many people walking the beaches there as  the tides come in or go out horrifically fast.

Living in a cold climate is no boon for any type of car and both gas and electric cars have their own problems. Ice in fuel lines is not a problem with electric cars.

HI:Had the same reading experience!!My dad went over in mid 43 and was there through some of the resettlement in latter part of 45.
He was in the REME corps.
His letters written to my mom were done to help ease the pain of distance and the scary unknown. I read a few but I felt I was intruding on their private lives(both passed a decade ago)with one having a lock of my moms hair in the envelope.
I have a small box with at least a 100 communicates back and forth that my mom kept from the war.
Our son went and saw Dunkirk(the movie) and before he went he asked about his granddad and the war so I read a few of the letters and sent him a scan of a post card my dad sent from Holland saying "Somewhere In Holland ,going across to Germany,going out to check a bridge head with infantry.Love"
My mom said death notices were sent by telegram to the door so no one wanted a telegram(or to open one).
I can't believe how strong my parents marriage was.
